metadata.sermon_start_end: Do you remember a song called “My Ma Told Me Not To Put Beans In My Ears”? The idea is a familiar one; the child never thought of putting beans in his ears until he was forbidden to do it. Then, of course, he was immediately seized [...] Dear people of God and heirs of the Covenant, do not fail to receive this mercy into your heart today, with joy. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon identifies the specific passage and its unique contribution (the term 'New Covenant'). However, it spends significant time on a general survey of Old Testament rebellion (Adam, Abraham, Moses, Canaan) rather than mining the specific linguistic or theological nuances of Jeremiah 31 that distinguish it from other prophetic promises.
quotes: The lesson from Jeremiah today is one of the most crucial passages of all.
This key passage gives us the term 'New Covenant,' or 'New Testament.'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more intensely on the specific imagery of 'writing on the heart' as opposed to the 'tablets of stone' to find what is unique to Jeremiah's voice compared to Ezekiel or Isaiah.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The historical context of the Babylonian exile is clearly established. However, there is no evidence of engagement with the original languages (Hebrew) or the specific literary structure of the oracle. The exegesis is largely historical-descriptive rather than philological.
quotes: Jeremiah was one of the two great prophets... who lived through the Babylonian invasion and exile.
Jeremiah wrote to comfort the Jews whose institutions and culture had been destroyed.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate insights from the Hebrew text (e.g., the meaning of 'berit' or the internal 'torah') to deepen the exposition beyond a general historical summary.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete, particularly regarding racial division in America. It avoids 'general truths' by providing two specific, harrowing narratives of grief and forgiveness. It addresses the zeitgeist of the 1990s (Howard Beach incident).
quotes: I refer to the sermon of two weeks ago on the Ten Commandments...
The white woman was a member in the church of my childhood... Her teenage son was killed by a car full of intoxicated joyriding black youths.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application links more directly to the 'internalization' of the law rather than just the 'act' of forgiveness, to stay closer to Jeremiah's specific promise.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional 'block' structure: historical background, then theological explanation, then contemporary stories. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' in a single movement; rather, the text is explained and then illustrated.
quotes: This brings us up to date in our Lenten series...
Here are two stories about two Christian women...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the contemporary stories into the verse-by-verse exposition so that the text and the modern reality interpret each other simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (rebellion/exile) and redemption (the New Covenant/Christ) are strong. Gratitude is present but less distinct, appearing as the 'obedience of faith.' The psychological depth of the 'paralysis of the will' aligns well with Dekker's requirement.
quotes: The story told by the Old Testament is a story of rebellion.
We are in a bad fix before God. Our story is one of prolonged and habitual disobedience.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Explicitly develop the 'gratitude' section as the natural result of the Spirit's work, rather than framing it primarily as 'true prayer' or 'seeking God's will.'

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'impasse' and 'judgment,' but the 'two ways'—the possibility of being lost—is softened by a focus on God's eventual mercy. The 'seriousness of the journey' is present, but the 'narrow way' is not sharply contrasted with 'destruction.'
quotes: This is part of what it means to come under God’s judgment; we must live with our various failures.
The prisoner can will to get out, but that’s no help.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematize the reality of 'being lost in time' (temporal loss) more sharply, especially in the context of the racial stories provided.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon moves from the impossibility of the law to the fulfillment in Christ's blood. The doctrine of the two natures is implied in the transition from Jeremiah to the Garden of Gethsemane.
quotes: In Jesus, the Son of God, the New Covenant is fulfilled.
Our disobedience becomes his burden to carry... The Lord has laid on him the iniquity of us all.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the 'writing on the heart' more explicitly to the person of Christ (the Word made flesh) rather than just the 'Holy Spirit' in a general sense.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it has thematic depth, it lacks the 'breadth' of detailed exegetical labor required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute threshold, providing more 'breadth' to the scriptural foundation.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily in its formal exegetical depth and its structural separation of exposition and application. It relies heavily on historical narrative and illustrative anecdotes rather than a rigorous 'recreation' of the specific Hebrew text. However, it succeeds in its psychological gravity and its clear Christological focus.
strengths: Strong psychological analysis of the 'paralysis of the will' (Augustine/Paul).
Concrete, non-sentimental application to racial conflict.
Clear Christological telos that avoids moralism.
weaknesses: Insufficient engagement with the original biblical languages and specific textual nuances.
Structural 'block' format separates exposition from application.
Duration is slightly under the 20-minute requirement for 'depth through breadth'.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a substantial homiletic effort, but it functions more as a 'speech about the gospel' illustrated by Jeremiah than a 'recreation of the Bible passage' itself. It is adequate but lacks the specific exegetical rigor Dekker demands.
